title: Canes Edge Pens 2-1 in Preseason Finale

Canes Edge Pens 2-1 in Preseason Finale 
Posted 10:39 p.m. yesterday Your friends e-mail addresses (comma separated): * Subject: * You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters 
Versteeg: It's always a bonus to win whether it's regular season or exhibition 
Ward: We've got a winning attitude and winning atmosphere going into the regular season By Michael Smith 
Raleigh, N.C. — It doesn’t amount to anything in the standings, but that’s just fine. After dropping a pair of games to begin the preseason, the Carolina Hurricanes won four straight to end their six-game exhibition slate. Tonight, it was a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins. 
Just over a week ago, the Penguins thumped the Hurricanes 7-3 in a game that crammed all 10 goals into the first 40 minutes. Tonight was a much more measured, controlled affair, with the Hurricanes nursing a 1-0 lead heading into the third period. 
Jordan Staal opened the scoring with just 30 seconds remaining in the first period, spinning out from behind the goal line, throwing the puck to the net and surprising Marc-Andre Fleury. 
Chris Terry scored what was ultimately the game-winning goal three minutes into the third period, streaking down the far wing and picking the far corner to make it a 2-0 game. 
Pittsburgh would get one back when Pascal Dupuis deposited a rebound past Cam Ward. 
Speaking of Ward, he was brilliant in his 60-minute body of work tonight. He made 34 saves on 35 shots. With the Canes ahead 1-0 in the second period, Evgeni Malkin burst into the zone with speed, blowing past a stick check from James Wisniewski. Ward sprawled out and flashed the pad, turning away two shots from Malkin to preserve the Canes’ one-goal advantage. 
The Hurricanes surrendered two power-play goals to the Penguins when the two teams met last week. Tonight was a much different story, as the Canes were a perfect 4-for-4 on the man disadvantage opposite a very dangerous Penguins five-man unit. 
The Hurricanes thought they had a 1-0 lead when Andrej Nestrasil centered the puck and it bounced in off Joakim Nordstrom. The official immediately waved it off, though there wasn’t much in the way of an explanation. 
Two weeks after skating onto the ice for beginning of training camp, the Hurricanes conclude the preseason with a 4-2-0 record and skate into the beginning of the regular season with a four-game winning streak. It starts for real on Oct. 8, but this was a mighty fine start.
